author: HumanEquivalentUnit
body:
`Where-Object -Property x` if given a property name it casts the value to bool and uses that as the filter test, but if given a method name it seems to check whether the method exists (getting the overload definitions and casting those to bool?), e.g.:
```
# filter out empty string, because Length 0 -> boolean false
PS C:\> "test", "", "test2" | Where -property Length
test
test2
# try with getter method name, by comparison
PS C:\> "test", "", "test2" | Where -property get_Length
test

test2
```

This feels inconsistent one way or another - if it should work with a method name, then it should call the method and use the return value, like `foreach-object -membername` does. But since the parameter is called `-Property` it should only take property names, and have another `-MemberName` property to work on arbitrary members.

With a wildcard:

```
PS C:\> "test" | where -Property L*
where : Input name "L*" is ambiguous. It can be resolved to multiple matched members. Possible matches include: Length LastIndexOf LastIndexOfAny.
```

Why is it matching a "property" wildcard to method names, when it can't use method names sensibly?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Good points;  to align the behavior with `ForEach-Object`, it seems to me  we could:

* add a parameter _alias_  for the existing `-Property` parameter named `-MemberName` and make it support method names too.

* add an `-ArgumentList` / `-Args` parameter to support passing arguments to method calls (in the implicit-Boolean-result scenario that would be fine; the syntax is perhaps a little confusing if an operator such as `-EQ` and operand (`-Value`) are also specified, but it should work).

title: "Where-Object -Property ..." should not accept method names because they're not properties
